Award.AwardTitle: CCCC Increasing Capacity & Enhancing Tribal Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cankdeska Cikana Community College is dedicated to community capacity building via educational opportunities. Through strategic planning efforts, CCCC has carefully crafted a plan that will strengthen and sustain STEM courses and programs by:
1. actively recruiting new talent (students and faculty) and raising the STEM bar by providing support to existing STEM curriculum through hiring highly qualified STEM faculty, research and development, and PEER tutoring;
2. implementing an innovative mathematics curriculum paradigm that will approach mathematics from three alternative (Accelerated, Slice, and Extended) directions aside from the traditional 15 week model; and
3. leveraging existing partnerships to provide a 4-year degree program through face-to-face, hybrid, and interactive video networking (IVN) course delivery.

Intellectual Merit: CCCC will achieve higher enrollment goals and retain students to matriculation into four-year institutions through recruitment and retention strategies that implement innovative tactics of math course advancement from 4 directions. Students will increase their ability to complete remedial and advanced mathematics through: 1) Accelerated Mathematics Academy (AMA); 2) use of mastery learning paradigm in extended math courses; 3) utilization of a Slice model for course engagement; and/or 4) continuation of the traditional 15 week semester approach. The college will increase STEM instructional capacity and improve research capabilities through the role modeling of a research environment that recognizes the importance of culture in relation to STEM. Additional STEM faculty with STEM credentials will enhance existing services and free up time for all faculty to focus on the development of intellectual and innovative models for learning. Evaluative processes will allow CCCC to build on existing pedagogical practices as well as cultivating new cutting edge practices.

Broader Impact: This project encompasses a comprehensive strategy to scaffold on existing education models that will implement a strategy for success through recruitment, support, and retention. A current student population averaging 245 students that are predominantly Native American of high poverty levels will be served. Opportunities for incoming freshman will increase college readiness with the AMA while attracting existing students that may have had disparities in the past. Successful implementation of this goal will help provide the paradigm necessary to promote a sustainable program and the backing to keep students on a path to successful matriculation into mainstream institutions. Additional STEM faculty expands the college's ability to explore proven models while increasing capacity to conduct research that will lead to dissemination through peer reviewed publications and conferences. The successful outcome of this project will increase STEM enrollment in mainstream universities. Broader outcomes focus on increasing STEM graduates that will serve as engineers, scientists, and mathematicians both inside and outside of Native American communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cankdeska Cikana Community College ICE-TI Project Outcomes

 

The Cankdeska Cikana Community College ICE-TI project, begun in 2013, had two goals:

Goal 1: Restructure mathematics instruction and learning.

Goal 2: To enhance and expand STEM resources.

 

CCCC implemented an innovative mathematics curriculum using Hawkes Learning System (HLS). The self-paced, mastery learning program allowed accelerated learning through the three developmental math course sequence (Pre-Algebra, Introductory Algebra, and Intermediate Algebra) to allow students to complete courses in less than one semester if they wished. Math placement tests (ACT Compass 2013-2017, SAT Accuplacer 2017-2019) determined in which course a student was placed. The HLS provided immediate feedback designed to increase student confidence, motivation, and persistence. Students worked independently and during set classroom times.

 

Faculty served as mentors in the classroom and during math lab hours; students also had access to peer tutors and other college tutoring programs. The style of pedagogy and HLS changed over time; HLS moved from disk-based software to internet-based access. Class structure moved from a less structured approach to set classroom times. The physical space was adapted to accommodate individualized learning with faculty consultation.

 

The faculty role in the classroom moved from a teacher-centered pedagogy to a supportive, coaching role, allowing faculty to teach math and to provide other needed non-academic supports to students, with a mentoring approach. Instructor availability was expanded through math lab hours; coordination of lab hours to eliminate overlap of faculty insured that faculty were exceedingly accessible to students during as many hours per day as possible. Continuing education and sharing of professional development opportunities between the math faculty ensured common expectations across all classes and consistency for students.

 

Math lab hours with instructors were coordinated and combined with other Professional Tutor services provided at the college; also, peer math tutors, trained and supervised by the math instructors, worked within classes. The HLS curricula were provided to the Professional Tutor; all peer tutors had worked through the HLS courses prior to qualifying as a tutor and were able to use those experiences to better assist students, not only the curricula, but with idiosyncrasies in the software. Cooperation also occurred between instructors and student support services personnel to resolve student non-academic issues.

 

From Fall 2013 through Fall 2019, 604 students enrolled in math courses. The students were more likely female and in their late 20?s; the percent of students who are male has slowly increased since 2013, from 34% Fall 2013 to 46% Fall 2019. Students? ages have slightly dropped, from 27-29 years old for the first 3 years to 24-25 years old Fall 2019. The percent of full-time students (75%) has dropped to approximately 55% during that time period. These patterns mirror changes in the overall CCCC student population.

 

The project increased student access to technology in the math and science classrooms, with student access to high-quality lab equipment for completing research in an on-site research facility comparable to any other institution of higher learning. Students gained valuable experience presenting their research at conferences, made possible by funds provided for travel.

 

Over the life of the ICE-TI project, it has faced and adapted to many challenges, from flooding roads, blizzards, intermittent internet access, very diverse student learning styles and situations, staff changes, changes in testing method for placing students in math courses, to the current COVID situation. In each case, staff and students have responded with creativity and flexibility. The current situation is a good example; during the spring 2020 semester faculty immediately converted to virtual classes and consultation. They have diligently worked to dramatically improve their capacity to offer quality math and science education using virtual methods. They also have developed a process for socially distanced individual meetings with students who are unable to solve a dilemma using virtual methods. Although some students have decided to delay enrollment because of dilemmas with virtual learning, enrollment for the fall 2020 semester has been very good.

 

The project has been disseminated at local, regional and national conferences: ICE-TI program information was disseminated at regional and national conferences: North Dakota Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges, Bismarck, ND, October 18-20; FALCON Conference, Denver, CO, October 24-28, 2019; INBRE Conference, Grand Forks, ND, October 18, 2019; American Evaluation Association Annual Conference, Minneapolis, MN, Nov 11 ? 16, 2019. Abstracts for presentation were accepted for the spring AISES and AIHEC conferences; however, the conferences were cancelled due to the pandemic.
